episode_summary: Listener-submitted curios sparked chats about Britainâ€™s windiest spot, a toilet-related spark to the Second World War, an eponymous surgical incision with a panhandle shape, and the creamed-corn smell associated with stem cell transplants. The hosts riffed through the facts with extra historical and medical tidbits and plenty of side tangents.

facts.fact: The windiest place in the UK is the butt of Lewis.
A soldier who spent too long on the toilet because of an upset stomach caused the start of World War II?
Now the incision is called Fanon Steel, because Fanon Steel in German means Panhandle, okay? But the surgeon who first described it was called Herman Johannes Fanon Steel.
when you get to stem cell transplant, you will stink of creamed corn for a couple of days.
